'''Nikola Jokić''' ({{lang-sr-cyr|Никола Јокић}}, {{IPA-sh|nǐkola jôkitɕ|pron}} ({{Audio-nohelp|SR - Nikola Jokic.oga|listen}}); born February 19, 1995) is a Serbian professional [[basketball]] player who is a [[Center (basketball)|center]] for the [[Denver Nuggets]] of the [[National Basketball Association]] (NBA). A four-time [[NBA All-Star]], he has been named to the [[All-NBA Team]] on four occasions (including three first-team selections), and won the [[NBA Most Valuable Player Award]] for the [[2020–21 NBA season|2020–21]] and [[2021–22 NBA season|2021–22]] seasons.<ref name="2021 MVP" /><ref name="2022 MVP" /> He represents the [[Serbia men's national basketball team|Serbian national team]].

Nicknamed "'''the Joker'''",<ref name=":1" /> Jokić was selected by the Nuggets in the second round of the [[2014 NBA draft]]. He was voted to the [[NBA All-Rookie First Team]] in [[2015–16 NBA season|2016]]. In the [[2018–19 NBA season]], while leading the Nuggets to the [[2019 NBA playoffs|Western Conference Semifinals]], he received his first All-Star and All-NBA First Team selections. In the following season, he once again received All-Star and All-NBA honors, while leading his team to the [[2020 NBA playoffs|Western Conference Finals]]. Jokić ranks among the top 10 on the all-time list of the NBA players with the most [[triple-doubles]] (regular season and playoffs), where he is the leading European player and center, and he holds the record for fastest triple-double (achieved in 14 minutes and 33 seconds).<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eurohoops.net/en/nba-news/989153/nikola-jokic-ties-bob-cousy-for-10th-place-in-all-time-triple-double-list/|title=Nikola Jokic ties Bob Cousy for 10th place in all-time triple-double list|date=December 21, 2019 |publisher=eurohoops.net|access-date=December 24, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://deadspin.com/well-that-was-a-spectacular-historic-game-from-nikola-1823059918|title=Well That Was A Spectacular, Historic Game From Nikola Jokic|first=Patrick|last=Redford|access-date=February 16, 2018}}</ref> He also won a silver medal at the [[Basketball at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2016 Summer Olympics]].

==Early life==
Jokić was born in the city of [[Sombor]] in the [[Vojvodina|northern part]] of [[Serbia]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|date=March 26, 2017|title=Nikola Jokic on Growing Up in Serbia, Racing Horses as a Kid and Adjusting to NBA Life in America|url=https://www.slamonline.com/nba/nikola-jokic-nuggets-interview/|access-date=March 26, 2021|website=SLAM|language=en}}</ref> He grew up in a cramped two-bedroom apartment that housed him and his two brothers, both parents and grandmother.<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|last=Sepkowitz|first=Leo|title=Born of a New Eastern Europe, Nikola Jokic Leads a Generation to NBA Stardom|url=https://bleacherreport.com/articles/2692809-born-of-a-new-eastern-europe-nikola-jokic-leads-a-generation-to-nba-stardom|access-date=March 26, 2021|website=Bleacher Report|language=en}}</ref> His father was an agricultural engineer.<ref>{{Cite web|date=August 28, 2019|title=Nikola Jokic: Serbia's beloved big man of basketball|url=https://www.france24.com/en/20190828-nikola-jokic-serbia-s-beloved-big-man-of-basketball|access-date=March 26, 2021|website=France 24|language=en}}</ref> Jokić developed a love of basketball early in his life playing with his two older brothers, who were a decade older. Strahinja, the oldest brother, played basketball in Europe and Nemanja, the second oldest, played college basketball at the [[Detroit Titans men's basketball|University of Detroit Mercy]].<ref name=":4" /><ref>{{Cite web|title=Nemanja Jokic - Men's Basketball|url=https://detroittitans.com/sports/mens-basketball/roster/nemanja-jokic/18|access-date=March 26, 2021|website=University of Detroit Mercy Athletics|language=en}}</ref> The brothers are friends with former NBA player [[Darko Miličić]].<ref>{{cite news|date=February 8, 2017|title=The Joker: Nikola Jokic Gets Serious In Denver|work=si.com|url=https://www.si.com/nba/2017/02/08/nikola-jokic-denver-nuggets-the-joker-serbia-darko-milicic|access-date=February 12, 2017}}</ref> Jokić also loved horse racing as a child and competed as an amateur, a passion he still holds today.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|last=Beck|first=Howard|title=The Way of the Joker|url=https://bleacherreport.com/articles/2741818-the-way-of-the-joker-nikola-jokic|access-date=March 26, 2021|website=Bleacher Report|language=en}}</ref>

==Professional career==

===Mega Basket (2012–2015)===
Jokić played youth basketball in [[KK Vojvodina Srbijagas|Vojvodina Srbijagas]], where he became a dominant figure and received interest from bigger teams. In the summer of 2012, Jokić signed a contract with [[KK Mega Basket|Mega Vizura]], although in the first season with the team he played mostly for their junior team in 2012–13. At the age of 17, he appeared in 5 games of the [[Basketball League of Serbia|Serbian League]] and averaged 1.8 points and 2 rebounds in 10.2 minutes per game. In the 2013–14 season, he saw more minutes on the court for the senior team. Over 25 [[2013–14 ABA League|Adriatic League]] games, he averaged 11.4 points, 6.4 rebounds and 2.5 assists per game. He also played 13 games with the team in the [[2013–14 Basketball League of Serbia|Serbian League]] and had similar production, averaging 10.9 points, 6 rebounds and 3.3 assists per game.

On June 26, 2014, Jokić was selected by the [[Denver Nuggets]] with the 41st overall pick in the [[2014 NBA draft]]<ref>{{cite web|last1=Carbaugh|first1=Dane|title=Denver takes Nikola Jokić with the No. 41 pick in the 2014 NBA Draft|url=https://www.sbnation.com/nba/2014/6/26/5848212/nba-draft-results-2014-denver-nuggets-nikola-jokic|work=SBNation.com|date=June 26, 2014|access-date=June 27, 2014}}</ref> and following this and the departure of [[Ratko Varda]], he became one of the team leaders in the 2014–15 season. surpassing Wilt Chamberlain for the most triple-doubles all time by a center with 79.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://clutchpoints.com/nuggets-news-nikola-jokic-resets-wilt-chamberlain-record-that-will-stand-the-test-of-time/|title=Nikola Jokic resets Wilt Chamberlain record that will stand the test of time|website=ClutchPoints|last=Villas|first=Rexwell|date=November 3, 2022|access-date=November 3, 2022}}</ref> On November 23, Jokić posted 39 points, 10 rebounds and nine assists, as the Nuggets beat the Oklahoma City Thunder in a 131–126 overtime win.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-11-23 |title=Jokic has 39 points, Nuggets outlast Thunder 131-126 in OT |url=https://www.espn.com/nba/recap/_/gameId/401468423 |access-date=2022-11-25 |website=ESPN.com |language=en}}</ref> On December 10, Jokić recorded his 80th career triple-double with 31 points, 12 rebounds, 14 assists and four blocks in a 115–110 win over the [[Utah Jazz]]. He became only the second player in NBA history to put up at least 31/12/14/4 in a game after [[LeBron James]].<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-10 |title=Jokic scores 31 in triple-double, Nuggets top depleted Jazz |url=https://www.espn.com/nba/recap/_/gameId/401468548 |access-date=2022-12-11 |website=ESPN.com |language=en}}</ref> On December 14, Jokić scored a season-high 43 points on 17-of-20 shooting from the field, along with 14 rebounds, eight assists, and five steals in a 141–128 win over the [[Washington Wizards]].<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-12-14 |title=Jokic scores 43 as Nuggets down ex-mates, Wizards 141-128|url=https://www.espn.com/nba/recap?gameId=401468577 |access-date=2022-12-15 |website=ESPN.com |language=en}}</ref> On December 18, Jokić put up a triple-double with 40 points, career-high 27 rebounds, and 10 assists in a 119–115 win over the [[Charlotte Hornets]]. ===Junior national team===
Jokić was a member of the [[Serbia men's national under-19 basketball team|Serbian U-19 national basketball team]] that won the silver medal at the [[2013 FIBA Under-19 World Championship]]. Over eight tournament games, he averaged 7.1 points, 5 rebounds and 1.5 assists per game.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nikola JOKIC Player Profile|url=http://archive.fiba.com/pages/eng/fa/player/p/pid/106812/sid/9616/tid/96799/_/2013_FIBA_U19_Championship_for_Men/index.html|website=FIBA.com|access-date=November 7, 2014}}</ref> 

===Senior national team===
[[File:Rio 2016 - Men's basketball USA-SRB (29168433900).jpg|thumb|220px|Jokić defending [[Kevin Durant]] at the [[2016 Summer Olympics]] in Rio de Janeiro.]]
He represented [[Serbia men's national basketball team|Serbia]] at the [[2016 FIBA World Olympic Qualifying Tournament – Belgrade|2016 FIBA World Olympic Qualifying Tournament]] in Belgrade, where he earned tournament MVP honors while averaging 17.8 points, 7.5 rebounds and 2.8 assists per game.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nikola JOKIC Player Profile|url=http://www.fiba.com/sr/oqt/serbia/2016/Nikola-JOKIC|website=FIBA.com|access-date=July 11, 2016}}</ref>
At the [[Basketball at the 2016 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2016 Summer Olympics]], Jokić and Serbia won the silver medal, after losing to the [[United States men's national basketball team|United States]] in the final game 96–66.<ref>{{cite news|title=Rio Olympics 2016: USA beat Serbia in men's basketball to win last gold of Games|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/olympics/36727948|access-date=September 18, 2017|work=BBC Sport|date=August 21, 2016}}</ref>

On May 24, 2019, Jokić announced he would play for Serbia at the [[2019 FIBA Basketball World Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Jokić: Igraću u Kini|url=https://www.b92.net/sport/kosarka/vesti.php?yyyy=2019&mm=05&dd=24&nav_id=1546015|website=b92.net|access-date=May 24, 2019}}</ref> At the 2019 FIBA Basketball World Cup, the national team of Serbia was dubbed as favorite to win the trophy,<ref>{{cite news |last1=Curkovic |first1=Igor |title=FIBA Basketball World Cup Power Rankings, Volume 3 |url=http://www.fiba.basketball/basketballworldcup/2019/news/fiba-basketball-world-cup-power-rankings-volume-3 |access-date=September 14, 2019 |work=FIBA.basketball |date=August 28, 2019}}</ref> but was eventually upset in the [[2019 FIBA Basketball World Cup final round|quarterfinals]] by [[Argentina national basketball team|Argentina]].<ref>{{cite news |title=Argentina upsets Olympic silver medalist Serbia in FIBA World Cup quarterfinals |url=https://olympics.nbcsports.com/2019/09/10/argentina-serbia-fiba-world-cup/ |access-date=September 14, 2019 |work=NBC Sports |date=September 10, 2019}}</ref> With wins over the United States and [[Czech Republic national basketball team|Czech Republic]], it finished in fifth place.<ref>{{cite news |title=Serbia defeats USA in FIBA World Cup consolation round play |url=https://www.nba.com/article/2019/09/12/fiba-world-cup-usa-serbia-game-recap |access-date=September 14, 2019 |work=NBA.com |date=September 12, 2019}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last1=T. |first1=P. |title=Bogdanović ponovo briljirao – Srbiji peto mesto u Kini |url=https://www.b92.net/sport/kina2019/vesti.php?nav_id=1591176 |access-date=September 14, 2019 |date=September 14, 2019 |language=sr}}</ref> Jokić was the second-best player on the team behind [[Bogdan Bogdanović (basketball)|Bogdan Bogdanović]], averaging 11.5 points, 7.5 rebounds and 4.8 assists over eight games, while shooting 68.0% from the field.

On June 15, 2022, Jokić announced he would return to the national team, after 3 years, for the [[2023 FIBA Basketball World Cup qualification (Europe)|2023 FIBA World Cup qualifiers]] and the [[EuroBasket 2022]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Jokić potvrdio da će igrati za reprezentaciju Srbije |url=https://www.rts.rs/page/sport/sr/story/37/kosarka/4850388/nikola-jokic-srbija-potvrda-reprezentacija.html |date=August 25, 2022 |language=sr}}</ref> He led Serbia to a perfect 5–0 record and first place in [[EuroBasket 2022 Group D|Group D]] at the EuroBasket 2022, but was eventually upset in the [[EuroBasket 2022 knockout stage|Round of 16]] by [[Italy national basketball team|Italy]] despite his 32-point, 13-rebound, 4-assist and 2-steal outing.<ref>{{Cite web |date=2022-09-11 |title=Stuff of dreams: Italy shock Serbia again |url=https://www.fiba.basketball/eurobasket/2022/news/stuff-of-dreams-italy-shock-serbia-again |access-date=2022-09-11 |website=FIBA.basketball |language=en}}</ref> Jokić was the best player on the team, averaging 21.7 points, 10.0 rebounds, 4.3 assists and 1.8 steals over six games, while shooting 66.2 percent from the field, 46.2 percent from three-point range, and 90.9 percent from the free throw line.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Nikola JOKIC at the FIBA EuroBasket 2022 |url=https://www.fiba.basketball/eurobasket/2022/player/Nikola-Jokic |access-date=2022-09-11 |website=FIBA.basketball |language=en}}</ref>

==Player profile==
Standing {{convert|6|ft|11|in|m|2}} and weighing {{convert|284|lbs|kg|0}}, Jokić plays exclusively at the [[Center (basketball)|center]] position.<ref name=Reference>{{cite web |title=Nikola Jokić Stats |url=https://www.basketball-reference.com/players/j/jokicni01.html |website=Basketball Reference|publisher=[[Sports Reference]]|access-date=June 12, 2021}}</ref> Through the 2021–22 season, Jokić's career averages are 19.7 points, 10.4 rebounds, and 6.2 assists per game.<ref name=Reference/>

Jokić is considered by many to be the greatest passing big man in NBA history. As a playmaker, Jokić uses his size and vision to set up his teammates for scores, often through a variety of no looks and unique deliveries.<ref name=FTE2101>{{cite web |last1=McBride |first1=T.J. |title=The Nuggets Look Mediocre, But Nikola Jokić Is Setting The World On Fire |url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/the-nuggets-look-mediocre-but-nikola-jokic-is-setting-the-world-on-fire/ |website=[[FiveThirtyEight]] |access-date=June 12, 2021 |date=January 22, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Kasabian |first1=Paul |title=Clippers' Doc Rivers Says Nikola Jokic Is Best Passing Big Man He's Ever Seen |url=https://bleacherreport.com/articles/2908261-clippers-doc-rivers-says-nikola-jokic-is-best-passing-big-man-hes-ever-seen |website=Bleacher Report |language=en|access-date=June 12, 2021 |date=September 8, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=O'Donnell |first1=Ricky |title=Nikola Jokic is playing like the NBA MVP right now |url=https://www.sbnation.com/nba/2021/1/25/22216980/nikola-jokic-mvp-denver-nuggets-stats-highlights-passing |website=[[SB Nation]] |language=en |access-date=June 12, 2021 |date=January 25, 2021}}</ref> His techniques, in particular his one-handed passes, have drawn comparisons to those of a [[water polo]] player.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cacciola |first1=Scott |title=Nikola Jokic Plays Basketball as if It's Water Polo |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/22/sports/basketball/nikola-jokic-nuggets-water-polo.html |website=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=June 12, 2021 |date=September 22, 2020}}</ref> Playing at a slow and deliberate pace, Jokić often pauses upon receiving the ball to survey the floor for defensive mistakes and potential openings.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Herring |first1=Chris |title=Nikola Jokić Is A Tortoise, And He's Beating All Of The Hares |url=https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/nikola-jokic-is-a-tortoise-and-hes-beating-all-of-the-hares/ |website=[[FiveThirtyEight]] |access-date=June 12, 2021 |date=September 24, 2020}}</ref>

In addition to his playmaking ability, Jokić is also a versatile scorer, capable of effectively finishing in the paint as well as hitting jump shots from midrange and the three-point arc.<ref name=FTE2101/><ref>{{cite web |last1=Cacciola |first1=Scott |title=Denver's Nikola Jokic Wins N.B.A.'s Most Valuable Player Award |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2021/06/08/sports/basketball/nikola-jokic-mvp-nuggets.html |website=[[The New York Times]] |access-date=June 12, 2021 |date=June 8, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Bailey |first1=Andy |title=Nikola Jokic Just Dominated 1 of the Strongest MVP Fields Ever |url=https://bleacherreport.com/articles/2944312-nikola-jokic-just-dominated-one-of-the-strongest-mvp-fields-ever |website=[[Bleacher Report]] |access-date=June 12, 2021 |date=June 8, 2021}}</ref> During his first MVP season, Jokić shot .566 from the field and .388 from 3-point range.<ref name=Reference/> His signature move, the "Sombor Shuffle" (coined by Nuggets play-by-play announcer [[Chris Marlowe]] after Jokić's hometown of [[Sombor]]), involves jumping off his right foot before launching a high-arching fadeaway. Jokić developed the move during his recovery from an ankle injury in 2017. The unorthodox move is difficult to contest and has drawn comparisons to [[Dirk Nowitzki]]'s one-legged fadeaway.<ref>{{Citation|last1=Doctor|first1=Isaac|title=Nuggets star Nikola Jokic reveals true story behind creation of his special move 'Sombor Shuffle'|url=https://clutchpoints.com/nuggets-news-nikola-jokic-reveals-true-story-behind-creation-of-special-move-sombor-shuffle/|language=en|website=[[ClutchPoints]]|date=May 1, 2021 |access-date=May 25, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Kosmider |first1=Nick |title=Inside the birth of an envelope-pushing basketball mindset that turned Nikola Jokic into an All-Star |url=https://theathletic.com/1598437/2020/02/14/inside-the-birth-of-an-envelope-pushing-basketball-mindset-that-turned-nikola-jokic-into-an-all-star/ |website=[[The Athletic]] |access-date=June 12, 2021 |date=February 14, 2020 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Cohen |first1=Ben |title=The NBA Playoffs Are Really a Space Race |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/nikola-jokic-sombor-shuffle-eurostep-stepback-nba-playoffs-11601020759 |website=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |access-date=June 12, 2021 |date=September 25, 2020}}</ref>

==Records==
*Highest single-season player efficiency rating in NBA history (32.85).

*Fastest triple-double in NBA history (14 minutes and 33 seconds).
*Only NBA player to be selected in the second round of the common era draft to win the MVP award.
*Only NBA player to reach at least 2,000 points, 1,000 rebounds, and 500 assists in a single season.
*Only NBA player to average at least 25 points, 10 rebounds, and 8 assists per game on 52% field goal percentage in a single season.
*Only NBA player to average at least 25 points, 13 rebounds, and 7 assists per game in a single season.
*Only NBA player to lead his team in all five major statistics (points, rebounds, assists, steals, blocks) and field goal percentage in the same season.
*Third NBA player since the NBA-ABA merger to post 30 points, 20 rebounds and 10 assists in a game: Denver Nuggets, {{nbay|2019}}
**Also achieved by [[David Lee (basketball)|David Lee]] (New York Knicks, {{nbay|2009}}), and [[DeMarcus Cousins]] (New Orleans Pelicans, {{nbay|2017}})
